title: On anniversary of grandfather's death, emotional Kyrie Irving scores 50 in Nets debut
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Jeff Zillgitt breaks down how talented the Pelicans roster is this season. USA TODAY

NEW YORK — For Kyrie Irving, his Brooklyn Nets debut carried profound professional and personal significance.

On the court, Irving dug into his back of tricks – reverses, 3-pointers, creative use of the backboard, elite dribbling – and torched the Minnesota Timberwolves for 50 points in a game the Timberwolves won 127-126 in overtime.

As Irving left Barclays Center, he told USA TODAY Sports, “This is bigger than basketball.”

One year ago to the day, Irving’s grandfather, George Larson, died, and it had a devastating effect on Irving, who told reporters earlier this month the experience made basketball seem irrelevant, and in turn, it forced him to re-evaluate his priorities on and off the court.

Irving, who grew up nearby in West Orange, New Jersey, discovered he wanted to be closer to home, near his friends and family. He left Boston for Brooklyn in free agency to find some inner peace.

“I just had to make choice to be happy out there,” Irving said. “My grandfather would only want it that way for me. He was my biggest fan. He was definitely in there tonight. I felt him, and I know he’s going to be with me.”

The emotions welled before the opening tip. “I was just trying to play it as cool as I could,” he said. “It was going to be a tough day regardless. Yesterday was tougher than today just talking to my grandmother, talking to my dad, talking to my sister. Today, I made a conscious choice when I woke up to be grateful for the day and every day going forward.”

And just before the game, Irving addressed the home crowd, saying, “Oh man, I am eternally grateful to be here, to be back home in front of you guys. On behalf of all of us … Oh man, sorry, it is just hitting me right now. I appreciate you guys. I look forward to you guys supporting us all season. Let’s go, Nets.”

He was overcome with emotion. The reality of actually playing for the Nets struck deep.

Kyrie addresses the fans in Brooklyn on opening night 🙌 pic.twitter.com/n2yNK9OnqN — NBA on ESPN (@ESPNNBA) October 23, 2019

“I wasn’t trying to get too emotional or anything like that,” Irving said. “I’m just a Jersey kid playing for his home team. There’s nothing like it. It’s been brewing since the fourth grade. I didn’t know it was going to happen at this point or this age. But it’s here and I just want to take advantage of it and just be happy and have a sense of gratitude every time I step on the floor.”

Irving delivered a mesmerizing offensive performance. He had 12 points in the first quarter, 13 in the second, five in the third, 13 in the fourth and by the time overtime concluded, Irving had dropped 50 on the Timberwolves. He established a franchise record for most points in a Nets debut.

Kyrie Irving counted each defender he beat for the layup 😆 pic.twitter.com/3pFNI6jYC4 — SportsCenter (@SportsCenter) October 24, 2019

It was a joyous display of scoring, and if this is what the Kyrie Irving Era in Brooklyn is going to look like, Barclays Center will be a fun place to be this season.

During a thrilling burst of points late in the fourth quarter, Irving had nine points in 62 seconds. He finished 17-for-33 from the field, including 7-for-14 on 3-pointers. It was Irving’s third career game with at least 50 points.

Brooklyn Nets guard Kyrie Irving (11) attempts a pass against the Minnesota Timberwolves. (Photo: Andy Marlin, USA TODAY Sports)

“If the game calls for you to get 50, get 50,” Nets coach Kenny Atkinson said. “There will be other nights when it’s 15 assists.”

Irving had a chance to deliver a victory on the game’s final possession, but he slipped while trying to make a move and didn’t get off a good shot with time running out on the clock.

50 points

0 turnovers



The Kyrie era started with a 💥 in Brooklyn pic.twitter.com/8StohNWMrm — SportsCenter (@SportsCenter) October 24, 2019

Irving dismissed the importance of scoring at least 50 points for the third time in his career. “The job wasn’t done,” he said. “None of that stuff matters if you don’t get a win.”

Still, the game had meaning. Nets fans chanted, “Kyrie’s home, Kyrie’s home” as he shot free throws in the fourth quarter. As introspective as Irving is, it’s a night he won’t forget.
description: One year to the day of his grandfather's death, Kyrie Irving - a New Jersey native - set a team record by scoring 50 points in his Nets debut.
